com.itko.lisa.coordinator

Interface Coordinator

  • All Superinterfaces:
    com.itko.lisa.net.LisaServerObject, com.itko.util.MonitoredObject, com.itko.lisa.coordinator.SyncPointSupport
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    SuiteCoordinator, TestCoordinator
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    com.itko.lisa.coordinator.BaseCoordinator, StagedSuite

    public interface Coordinator
extends com.itko.util.MonitoredObject, com.itko.lisa.coordinator.SyncPointSupport, com.itko.lisa.net.LisaServerObject
    This is the interface for a Coordinator. Coordinators load and execute test cases. Applications that want to drive test case execution should learn this interface.

    The most simple way to run a test is to create a test run XML document. This document supplies all the data needed to load and stage a test, for example:

    • location of the global registry for all tests
    • location of the test case to load and execute for this run
    • what simulators to use and how many concurrent instances to run on each one

    To use the run file approach, simply call the init() method with the run file as a argument, then call startTest() to execute the test.

    If you prefer to manually instruct the coordinator about how to stage a test, you must execute most of the methods in this interface at the appropriate time. This is not difficult, but somewhat tedious.

    Yet another approach to reduce the tediousness is to call init() with a valid run file, but interactively modify the run before you call startTest(). Anything specified by the run file can be changed by calling the appropriate override method in this interface.

    Once the test has started, the only methods that will have any effect are:

  • getName()
  • getStatus()
  • getTestEventMgr()
  • addTestEventListener()
  • stopTest()
  • addSimulator()
  • addInstancesToSimulator()

See Also:
Simulator, TestCase

    • Field Detail

      • STATUS_NOINIT

        static final int STATUS_NOINIT
        Possible status of the Coordinator returned by Coordinator.getStatus()
        • STATUS_NOINIT: Object created but knows nothing (has not been initialized yet). Call init() successfully to set this status to STATUS_INIT
        • STATUS_INIT: Test case and run have been initialized, but test not started
        • STATUS_RUNNING: The test is currently running in the simulator(s)
        • STATUS_ENDED: The test has completed running and we are ready to clean up
        See Also:
        getStatus(), Constant Field Values

      • STATUS_INIT

        static final int STATUS_INIT
        See Also:
        STATUS_NOINIT, Constant Field Values

      • STATUS_RUNNING

        static final int STATUS_RUNNING
        See Also:
        STATUS_NOINIT, Constant Field Values

      • STATUS_ENDED

        static final int STATUS_ENDED
        See Also:
        STATUS_NOINIT, Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        java.lang.String getName()
                         throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        The coordinator's name is not necessarily unique throughout the network and is NOT a network name. It is granted in the run file or by calling setName(). This is NOT the best name to use to figure out what run doc a coordinator is running. Use getRunName() for that. Note that this is not a settable parameter. The name is assigned at construction by either the CoordinatorServer that created it or by whatever object constructed it.
        Returns:
        the name of the Coordinator
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getRunName

        java.lang.String getRunName()
                            throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This is the name given to the Run. It usually comes from the test case and run name from the staging doc. It may be the most unique way to identify a test that's running, so you might prefer this name to the Coordinator's name
        Returns:
        the name of this test run as defined in the Run XML document
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getUniqueId

        java.lang.String getUniqueId()
                             throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Names are great but there are so many, just ask the author typing this for proof ;) This method gives you access to a should-be-unique code for this particular Coordinator that should be useful if you need to coordinate objects within this context.
        Returns:
        a String of a unique GUID as a hex value
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getStatus

        int getStatus()
              throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This method can be used to track what the coordinator status is. Possible responses are:
        Returns:
        one of the following:
        • 0 (STATUS_NOINIT) not initialized (nothing do'n)
        • 1 (STATUS_INIT) has been initialized, but is not running
        • 2 (STATUS_RUNNING) the test is currently running
        • 3 (STATUS_ENDED) test case has ended running, coordinator is ready for cleanup
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        See Also:
        STATUS_NOINIT

      • getRunInfo

        RunInfo getRunInfo()
                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        When the Coordinator initially starts it is generally given a Run Document. This object contains the complete understanding of the parameters that were provided in that Run document. These can be changed by the Coordinator as the test is run, or other Lisa components do their thing, but that won't change this info object. This remains faithful to the original Run document info.
        Returns:
        a RunInfo document
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        See Also:
        RunInfo

      • addTestEventListener

        void addTestEventListener(TestEventListener tel,
                        int[] filter)
                          throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Use this method to hook into the event mechanism LOCALLY; use the RMI version for adding remote listeners. NOTE: The event listener classes are the only ones (at present typing) that are implemented differently in the Client object vs the actual Server object. This is obviously to support the messaging Topic delivery of events as transparently as possible.
        Parameters:
        tel - - is the listenter that will get the events
        filter - - an array that holds the list of events you want. See TestEventMgr for the list of what values mean what. Null or empty array means you will get the default filter, not noFilter, per the TestEvent javadoc
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        See Also:
        TestEvent.defaultFilter, TestEventMgr, TestEventListener, TestEvent

      • removeTestEventListener

        void removeTestEventListener(TestEventListener tel)
                             throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        The obvious complement to addTestEventListener so we can remove event listeners as needed
        Parameters:
        tel - - is the listenter to remove
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getDefaultReportHistoryParameters

        ParameterList getDefaultReportHistoryParameters()
                                                throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This coordinator will find if the default report generator is on, and if so, give you the ParameterList of the params. You can call statics on the report to know what history is desired
        Returns:
        null if there isn't a default report, or the params of it if there is one
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • notifyOfRemoteEventListener

        java.lang.String notifyOfRemoteEventListener(java.lang.String listenerId,
                                           int[] filter)
                                             throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                                                    TestRunException
        There is a JMS Topic related to this Coordinator that remote event listeners use to get events pushed into their consumers. Cool. But we have this whole optimizing away of event generation if no one is listening for the event. So we make our remote event listeners call a set of methods to basically declare their interest in events in order for them to get the name of the JMS Topic that we are broadcasting on. Tit for tat, right?
        Parameters:
        listenerId - some identifier of who this is (make it a GUID that you can remember from call to call)
        filter - the TestEvent filter to minimize undesired events
        Returns:
        the name of the JMS Topic you can access to get the events
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        TestRunException

      • updateRemoteEventListener

                             int[] filter)
                               throws java.rmi.RemoteException

      • startTest

        void startTest()
               throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                      TestRunException
        Starts execution of the test. Its main function to do so is to signal all simulators that are participating in the test to start executing the test case.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        TestRunException - if the test could not be started

      • getStartTime

        long getStartTime()
                  throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This method will tell you when the test was started. Just FYI...
        Returns:
        timestamp of when the test started, or 0 if it hasn't started yet
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getEstimatedEndTime

        long getEstimatedEndTime()
                         throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This method will try to tell you when the test should be done.
        Returns:
        number of milliseconds before the test will complete OR -1 if the test is set to run for a certain number of cycles OR indefinitely. Only if the test is set to run for a given time will this method help you out any.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getActualTestTime

        long getActualTestTime()
                       throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Once the test has ended, this method will tell you how long the Coordinator ran the test.
        Returns:
        length of test in milliseconds or -1 if it hasn't ended yet
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getTestStats

        TestRunInfo getTestStats()
                         throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Will report the info struct as a snapshot of what's going on on this test run. It has good stuff, like average trans time, total instances, etc.
        Returns:
        the TestRunInfo object current at the time of the call
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        See Also:
        TestRunInfo

      • getStats

        StatKeeper getStats()
                    throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Returns the whole stat keeper object (as a value since we are RMI) so you can look at the test run info & the step-by-step performance info
        Returns:
        a StatKeeper which has TestRunInfo and PerfInfo objects for each node in the model
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

        Throws:

      • hasTestErrorFired

        boolean hasTestErrorFired()
                          throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        While the Coordinator runs the test, it is checking for non-test fatal and fatal error events. It will tell you if such an event has fired by calling this method. The EVENT_NODEFAILED is considered non-fatal.
        Returns:
        true if errors like EVENT_ABEND have been fired during this test
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        See Also:
        TestEvent.isWholeTestFailureEvent()

      • getErrorEvents

        java.util.List<TestEvent> getErrorEvents()
                                         throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        If the test has received errors, here are the error events If the test has not failed, you will get null.
        Returns:
        a list of TestEvent objects or null
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getErrorEventListSize

        int getErrorEventListSize()
                          throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Return the size of the ErrorEvent list
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • makeMessageFromErrorEvents

        java.lang.String makeMessageFromErrorEvents()
                                            throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        If the test has received errors, you can call this method to get an error message produced from those error events. If the test has not failed, you will get null.
        Returns:
        a string of the (semi) human readable events for display
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • endTest

        void endTest(boolean immediately)
             throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This method will stop execution of the test. Use immediately only when absolutely necessary!
        Parameters:
        immediately - - answers the question do you want the current test iteration to finish to normal completion? If not, then the threads running the testcase are interrupted and terminated abruptly
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • setRunName

        void setRunName(java.lang.String runName)
                throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Used to set the name of this test run in all events. Use this to override the default run name given in the run file. Be careful not to change this name during test execution because the name may not be propogated to Simulators consistently. Set it before calling startTest()
        Parameters:
        runName - is the new name to use for this run of the test
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • fireTestEvent

        void fireTestEvent(TestEvent ev)
                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Simulators use this method to propogate events back to the coordinator so that they can be reported as requested. You can add your own events as long as they conform to the TestEvent object's policy. The two versions of this method are really just the two different ways you might want to call this method.
        Parameters:
        ev - - the TestEvent object to deliver to all test even consumers
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        See Also:
        TestEvent

      • fireTestEvents

        void fireTestEvents(TestEvent[] ev)
                    throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This method allows you to send multiple events in one method invocation, which is a cool thing to do for reducing RMI/threading noise.
        Parameters:
        ev - - an array of TestEvent objects to deliver to all test even consumers
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        See Also:
        fireTestEvent(com.itko.lisa.test.TestEvent)

      • raiseException

        void raiseException(TestRunException ex)
                    throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Simulators use this method to propogate a serious test execution error. This immediately terminates the test and reports the error to stdout. It is presumed that there has been some catostrphic event.
        Parameters:
        ex - the TestRunException that has ocurred
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
        See Also:
        TestRunException

      • destroy

        void destroy()
             throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Call this method to ensure that the Coordinator will release resources and not remain in any network collections. It is optional, as it will eventually be freed regardless. This method is called internally by the CoordinatorServer, but calling it more than once won't hurt anything.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getCurrentTests

        java.util.List<?> getCurrentTests()
                                  throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Get a list of all the currently running Tests -- this will generally be a list of 1 TestCase except when we are a Suite running in parallel
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

        Throws:

      • getDataSetManager

        com.itko.lisa.test.IDataSetManager getDataSetManager()
                                                     throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Returns a handle to the Data Set Manager. This method enables TestCase's running on the Simulator to acquire a handle to the Data Set Manager, which will be running on the Coordinator.
        Returns:
        a handle to the Data Set Manager
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • getDataSets

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,DataSet> getDataSets()
                                                    throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Returns the data sets of the test case. This method enables a TestCase running on the Simulator get a handle to the global data set instances, which will be running on the Coordinator.
        Returns:
        the data sets of the test case.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • configureForLoadTest

        void configureForLoadTest()
                          throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Tells the coord to prepare for a load test. This means changing a few filters, setting some cache timeout options, generally checking on things that could/would prevent a load test from working properly (you don't want pathfinder, you don't want profiling, you don't want the root logger set to debug, etc, etc
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • isLoadTesting

        boolean isLoadTesting()
                      throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Some components need to know if the coord is load testing, classic example is the TestRunPanel which would normally allow a pulldown to include all events. We can disable the pulldown for a load test.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException
